resources.audio

Class AudioBuffer

  • java.lang.Object
    • resources.audio.AudioBuffer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Resource

    public class AudioBuffer
extends java.lang.Object
implements Resource
    Stores a sound effect and can play through an AudioSource.

    • Field Summary

      Modifier and Type Field and Description

      Number of the audio buffer's channels.

      • AudioBuffer

        private AudioBuffer(@NotNull
                    java.io.File path)
        Initializes a new AudioBuffer to the given value.
        Parameters:
        path - sound file's relative path (with extension like "res/sounds/mySound.ogg")

    • Method Detail

      • getId

        public int getId()
        Returns the audio buffer's native OpenAL id. You should use it if you can't do anything else.
        Returns:
        the audio buffer's native OpenAL id

      • setLastActiveToNow

        public void setLastActiveToNow()
        Sets the audio buffer's last activation time to now.

      • refreshStore

        public void refreshStore()
        Loads the sound effect to the sound system.

      • hddToRam

        private void hddToRam()
        Loads the audio buffer's data from file to the RAM.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - failed to load the sound effect

      • ramToAction

        private void ramToAction()
        Loads the audio buffer's data from the RAM to the sound system. It may cause errors if the data isn't in the RAM.

      • actionToRam

        private void actionToRam()
        Removes the audio buffer's data from the sound system. It may cause errors if the data isn't in the sound system.

      • ramToHdd

        private void ramToHdd()
        Removes the audio buffer's data from the RAM. It may cause errors if the data isn't in the RAM.

      • loadSound

        public static AudioBuffer loadSound(@NotNull
                                    java.io.File path)
        Loads a sound effect from the given path. You can load a sound effect only once, if you try to load it twice, you get reference to the already loaded one.
        Parameters:
        path - sound effect's relative path (with extension like "res/sounds/mySound.ogg")
        Returns:
        audio buffer

      • getChannels

        public int getChannels()
        Returns the number of the audio buffer's channels.
        Returns:
        the number of the audio buffer's channels

      • getFrequency

        public int getFrequency()
        Returns the audio buffer's frequency.
        Returns:
        the audio buffer's frequency

      • getActionTimeLimit

        public long getActionTimeLimit()
        Returns the ACTION time limit. If the elapsed time since this audio buffer's last use is higher than this value and the audio buffer's data store policy is RAM or HDD, the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system. Later if you want to use this audio buffer, you should call the refreshStore method to load the data from file again.
        Returns:
        ACTION time limit (in miliseconds)
        See Also:
        refreshStore()

      • setActionTimeLimit

        public void setActionTimeLimit(long actionTimeLimit)
        Sets the ACTION time limit to the given value. If the elapsed time since this audio buffer's last use is higher than this value and the audio buffer's data store policy is RAM or HDD, the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system. Later if you want to use this audio buffer, you should call the refreshStore method to load the data from file again.
        Parameters:
        actionTimeLimit - ACTION time limit (in miliseconds)
        See Also:
        refreshStore()

      • getRamTimeLimit

        public long getRamTimeLimit()
        Returns the RAM time limit. If the elapsed time since this audio buffer's last use is higher than this value and the audio buffer's data store policy is HDD, the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system or even from RAM. Later if you want to use this texture, you should call the refreshStore method to load the data from file again.
        Returns:
        RAM time limit (in miliseconds)
        See Also:
        refreshStore()

      • setRamTimeLimit

        public void setRamTimeLimit(long ramTimeLimit)
        Sets the RAM time limit to the given value. If the elapsed time since this audio buffer's last use is higher than this value and the audio buffer's data store policy is HDD, the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sounds system or even from RAM. Later if you want to use this audio buffer, you should call the refreshStore method to load the data from file again.
        Parameters:
        ramTimeLimit - RAM time limit (in miliseconds)
        See Also:
        refreshStore()

      • getLastActive

        public long getLastActive()
        Returns the time when the audio buffer last time used.
        Returns:
        the time when the audio buffer last time used (in miliseconds)

      • getState

        @NotNull
public ResourceManager.ResourceState getState()
        Returns the audio buffer's state. It determines where the sound is currently stored.
        Returns:
        the audio buffer's state

      • getDataStorePolicy

        @NotNull
public ResourceManager.ResourceState getDataStorePolicy()
        Returns the audio buffer's data store policy. ACTION means that the audio buffer's data will be stored in the sound system. RAM means that the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system to RAM if it's rarely used. HDD means that the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system or even from RAM if it's rarely used. Later if you want to use this audio buffer, you should call the refreshStore method to load the data from file again.
        Returns:
        the texture's data store policy
        See Also:
        refreshStore()

      • setDataStorePolicy

        public void setDataStorePolicy(@NotNull
                               ResourceManager.ResourceState minState)
        Sets the audio buffer's data store policy to the given value. ACTION means that the sound's data will be stored in the sound system. RAM means that the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system to RAM if it's rarely used. HDD means that the audio buffer's data may be removed from the sound system or even from RAM if it's rarely used. Later if you want to use this audio buffer, you should call the refreshStore method to load the data from file again.
        Parameters:
        minState - data store policy
        See Also:
        refreshStore()
